properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong westerly winds, with gusts at times over 100 km/h, will continue today. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of significant freezing rain is expected. Locations: southern, central and western Newfoundland. Time span: this afternoon until early Wednesday morning. Remarks: Freezing rain has begun over much of southern Newfoundland and will move northward during the afternoon. Total amounts of up to 10 mm are possible for parts of central and western Newfoundland. Precipitation is expected to change to rain for all areas by early Wednesday morning. ### Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-04T06:20:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-03T14:21:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0601333475.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Persistent snow squalls are expected to develop Wednesday and continue into Thursday morning. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. 5 to 10 centimetres is expected by Wednesday evening. Wednesday night into Thursday morning the snow squalls may intensify locally and up to 15 centimetres is possible in the heaviest snow squalls. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-04T12:18:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-03T20:19:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4043747761.2019

properties.Summary:

Remarks: Freezing rain is expected to quickly transition through to rain this afternoon. Freezing rain should be limited to higher terrain as temperatures along the coast rise above freezing. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected tonight and Wednesday. Locations: Eagle River and Cartwright to L'Anse-au-Clair. Time span: this evening until Wednesday evening. Possible snowfall: 10 to 20 cm except 5 to 10 cm along the coast from Mary's Harbour to L'Anse-au-Clair. Remarks: Snow will begin in the Straits area this evening then spread to the rest of southeastern and central Labrador during the night. Areas along the coast from L'Anse-au-Clair to Mary's Harbour are likely to see less accumulation as the snow is expected to be wet and mix with ice pellets. However, areas inland along the Trans Labrador Highway could see up to 20 cm by Wednesday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-04T07:20:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-03T15:21:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0655374073.2019

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extended period of freezing rain and ice pellets expected to continue into the afternoon. Locations: southern New Brunswick. Time span: until early to mid afternoon. Remarks: Freezing rain and ice pellets will gradually change back to snow from west to east beginning this afternoon. The precipitation will briefly change to rain over extreme southeast regions. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-03T22:59:47-00:00

properties.Summary:

Remarks: Snow at times heavy will spread across northern region early this afternoon. Snow will likely mix with ice pellets with a risk of freezing rain for a time over east central regions. properties.Title: Update: High Water Advisory Alert Is Being Issued For The Roseau River From Gardenton To Dominion City
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a High Water Advisory for the Roseau River from Gardenton to Dominion City due to expected high flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions by the local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2019-12-04T12:30:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2019-12-03T12:35:50-06:00, 77000000-CB0A-92B7-C7E1-42C80B9C1DB4
Area: Roseau River from Gardenton to Dominion City
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong westerly winds will intensify along the Mackenzie Delta on Wednesday afternoon. The winds are expected to combine with fresh snowfall to give blizzard conditions over Tuktoyaktuk starting early Wednesday evening. The blizzard is forecast to continue until early Thursday. This winter storm watch may be upgraded to a blizzard warning when the timing of the winds becomes more certain. ### Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-04T09:22:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-03T17:23:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0913782377.2019
Area: Tuktoyaktuk - East Channel Region

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Atmospheric conditions could result in a deterioration in air quality. High concentrations of pollutants should develop this evening and persist until Wednesday morning. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-12-04T17:00:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal, 2019-12-03T20:49:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2153081413.2019
Area: Ashuapmushuan Wildlife Reserve area, Normandin - Péribonka area, Alma - Desbiens area, Saint-Félicien - Roberval area, Falardeau - Mont-Valin area, Sainte-Rose-du-Nord area, Ville de Saguenay area, Rivière-Éternité - Petit-Saguenay area, Tadoussac - Baie-Sainte-Catherine area

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. AIR QUALITY ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR GRAND FORKS (December 2, 2019 15:00 local Mountain time - Cranbrook) The Ministry of Environment & Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with the Interior Health Authority has issued an Air Quality Advisory for Grand Forks due to high concentrations of fine particulate matter that are expected to persist until weather conditions change. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. If you are experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, follow the advice of your health care provider. Staying indoors helps to reduce fine particulate exposure. Exposure is particularly a concern for pregnant women, infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-12-04T06:27:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2019-12-03T14:28:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3742455142.2019
Area: Boundary
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment
